historicEventInformations.remarks: date previously 1549 [Philadelphia Museum of Art, revised 2015]

pageContext.description:
Before settling in Wetzlar, Germany, about 1515, Hans Döring trained in the Wittenberg workshop of the German painter and printmaker Lucas Cranach the Elder (1472-1553). This work is reminiscent of Cranach's portrait style both in the general composition and in the treatment of the hands, facial features, and clothing.
[http://www.philamuseum.org/collections/permanent/102547.html?mulR=14351|1](accessed 21.03.2013)
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support:  47.6 x 38.4 cm (18 3/4 x 15 1/8 inches)
[Philadelphia Museum of Art, revised 2015]
pageContext.inscription:
- across top (fragmentary): [...] / ALTERS . IM . [...]1 . IARE . 1549 . ([...] aged [...]1 years, 1549; the date has been altered from 1520 or 1529, and a line above the present one, probably containing the sitter's name, has been removed.
[Philadelphia Museum of Art, revised 2015]

metadata.title: Portrait of a Nobleman (Possibly a Member of the Solms Family)

pageContext.provenance:
- Laurentine-Françoise (Bernage) Lelong (d. 1902), Paris, until d. 1902
- her estate sale, Galerie Georges Petit, Paris, December 8-10, 1902, no. 4. 
- possibly with Eugène Fischoff, Paris, 1907 [1]
- John G. Johnson (1841-1917), Philadelphia, possibly by 1907 and definitely by 1914, until d. 1917 [2]
- bequest to City of Philadelphia, 1917 (John G. Johnson Collection)

[1] Transcription of letter from Eugène Fischoff, Paris, to John G. Johnson, June 21, 1907 (curatorial file), referring to a Hans Mielich that Fischoff is shipping to Johnson. Cat. 736 was attributed to Mielich when first catalogued in Johnson Collection.
[2] W[ilhelm]. R[einhold]. Valentiner, Catalogue of a Collection of Paintings and Some Art Objects, vol. 3: German, French, Spanish and English Paintings and Art Objects, Modern Paintings (Philadelphia: John G. Johnson, 1914), p. 12, no. 736, illus. p. 240.
[Philadelphia Museum of Art, revised 2015]

titles.title: Portrait of a Nobleman (Possibly a Member of the Solms Family)
